title: chore: add release crates workflow

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

body:
## Summary


This PR contains these changes:
- Unified package version to `workspace.package.version`: https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/workspaces.html#the-package-table. 
- Added command `x crate-version` to create a version change
- Added command `x crate-publish` to publish crates
- Added CI workflow `release-crates` to publish crates by manual dispatch
- Refactored CI workflow `ci-rust` to a split workflow `reusable-rust-test` to support checking in workflow `release-crates`

`x crate-version` will use exact version to ensure the consistencies between each dependency. (for example `version = "=0.3.0"`)

All newly added x commands are internally driven by `cargo-workspaces`

<!-- Describe what this PR does and why. -->

title: chore: add debug_tool feature to improve debug dx

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

body:
## Summary
add debug_tool feature to support call debug_tool function in local debug environment(inspired by https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-analyzer/blob/661e7d2ac245f4fca099d982544b3c5408322867/crates/rust-analyzer/src/bin/main.rs#L97).
## User Guide
### adding debug util into your code
add debug_tool code at stop_point where you care like following
https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/pull/10899/files#diff-3fbb9f7dfbadceab7b0c89038c54de9851f25ae957a1f91aea05b0e46da2b209R329-R333
```rs
 #[cfg(feature = "debug_tool")]
    {
      use rspack_util::debug_tool::wait_for_signal;
      wait_for_signal("seal compilation");
    }

    self.compilation.seal(self.plugin_driver.clone()).await?;
```
###  build with debug feature
```sh
pnpm build:dev -- --features debug_tool // dev profile with debug_tool
pnpm build:release -- --features debug_tool // release profile with debug_tool

```
### run rspack
run the program with `RSPACK_DEBUG_STOP=1` will auto stop at your stop point
```sh
RSPACK_DEBUG_STOP=1 node bin/rspack.js -c '/Users/bytedance/github/rspack/examples/basic/rspack.config.cjs'
```
it will print the following command to tell you what to do to continue
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cc503117-1da5-4c8c-966e-c97075dea837)


### attach debugger or samply to the process
#### attach samply
copy the previous pid and run samply
```sh
samply record -p {PID}
```
#### attach lldb
Todo
### send signal to process to continue 
copy the previous command shown in your terminal to continue your process and the debugger & profiler will auto debug and profile your program
```sh
kill -SIGUSR2 {PID}
```
https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4048b890-1588-4c93-a12a-d04ff52696d8


## Related links

<!-- Related issues or discussions. -->

<!--- Check and mark with an "x" -->

- [ ] Documentation updated (or not required).

title: perf: improve parallelism of real content hash plugin

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

labels.name: release: performance
labels.description: release: performance related release(mr only)

body:
## Summary

Improve parallelism when calculating the real content hashes.

By recording the processed hashes and the hashes on which the current asset depends, if all have been processed, it is added to the current processing batch. Then process the batch together to prevent the number of tasks processed in parallel at one time from being too small, which would make the process approach sequential processing.

Before:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ea3a4ebb-3526-4a44-91f8-3fec0fc89ed9)

After:

title: feat: set module.ptr to None when cleanup the module

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

labels.name: release: feature
labels.description: release: feature related release(mr only)

body:
## Summary

<!-- Describe what this PR does and why. -->

### Clarify Access Methods for napi Module to Rust Module

- Primary access: Query `compilation.module_graph` using `module_identifier`

- Fallback for unregistered modules: Access via raw pointer when modules aren't yet stored in `compilation.module_graph` (e.g., during loader execution phase)

### Clarify napi Module Lifecycle

- Created when accessed via JavaScript API

- Lifecycle ends upon triggering `revoked_modules` hook

### Behavior When napi Module Lifecycle Ends

When JavaScript API accesses napi module properties after lifecycle termination:

- `module_identifier` query in `compilation.module_graph` returns undefined

- Raw pointer stored in napi module becomes `None`

- Throw an Error to the JavaScript side

title: feat(binding-builder): support using custom binding

labels.name: release: feature
labels.description: release: feature related release(mr only)

body:
## Summary

<!-- Describe what this PR does and why. -->

This PR supports using custom binding with environment variable `RSPACK_BINDING`.
_Path-to-binding_ is a path to the root of the binding package.

```
RSPACK_BINDING=path-to-binding
```
This is achieved by our already used `ast-grep` package to scan and replace the original content of module `@rspack/binding` and `@rspack/binding/package.json`.


In order to either use or test the new binding package (which contains support for custom plugin), this PR also adds support for exposing `experiments.createNativePlugin` which is an alias to the original plugin `create` and would throw error if there's any naming collision with the internal builtin plugins. `createNativePlugin` is used to create wrappers around native plugins:

```js
const MyPlugin = createNativePlugin("MyPlugin", (options) => {
 return options;
});

new MyPlugin({
 foo: "bar"
}).apply(compiler);
```

Tests are now containing two parts, the original binding and the builder testing binding. The latter part is to test if `rspck-binding-builder` successfully extended all the exposed symbols and functionalities provided by `crates/node_binding`. In order to cover that part, tests are written in a mixed style with the original rspack tests. With `test.filter.js`, these tests are only enabled when  running `test:base-builder` script in `rspack-test-tools`. I talked to @stormslowly about these changes to the workflows. Due to the complexity, I would separate the workflow change to a separate PR.


## Related links

<!-- Related issues or discussions. -->

## Checklist

<!--- Check and mark with an "x" -->

- [ ] Tests updated (or not required). Required, but to heavy to implement in the same PR.
- [ ] Documentation updated (or not required).

title: refactor: remove export info map on module graph

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

body:
## Summary

Integrate the export info into the exports info to reduce the time spent on searching for export info data. During the seal phase, a layer of partial instances is added to the module graph, causing a loop partial operation for each query, which incurs significant performance overhead. Moreover, export info is seldom used alone, and an export info must belong to an exports info. Therefore, they can be integrated. 

And also this PR refactors some things below:
- modify ExportInfo to `(ExportsInfo, Atom)` and keep the `as_data/as_data_mut` methods to find the data by finding ExportsInfoData first and then get its named export info data.
- no need to prefetch named exports any more, so just remove them and retain the logic of "nested".
- remove ExportInfoGetter and ExportInfoSetter, and extends the methods to ExportInfoData, finish the rerfactoring
- remove export info related methods on module graph and export info id.

title: fix: fix_issuer mgm not found panic

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

labels.name: release: bug fix
labels.description: release: bug related release(mr only)

body:
## Summary

The return value of `try_set_first_incoming` in `fix_issuer` may contain modules that have been removed, which will cause a `should mgm exist` panic. Here is a simple example:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/722be12e-be2a-40c1-a2f2-895a19cc50a9)

ModuleA deletes the references to moduleB and moduleC. When `try_set_first_incoming` is called, moduleB will be processed first due to the import order, and moduleC will be removed. In this case, the subsequent process continues to use moduleB, and the error `should mgm exist` will occur when looking for its parent element.

This PR will fix this bug and ensure that all modules returned by `try_set_first_incoming` exist.


<!-- Describe what this PR does and why. -->

title: chore(ci):  skip cross-env in webpack-test script

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

body:
## Summary
Currently, I can't found why the `Error: kill ENOSYS`([ref](https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/actions/runs/15921216248/job/44908652198#step:9:224)) happens.

But we can see that
1. The test has run for 20 mins, and hit the time-out threshold, Github action try to kill the process(***the cross-env process***)
2. When cross-env process propergated the kill signal to the spawned process(***the Jest***), but the Jest process could not be found.

So We can conclude that the Jest process has already exited, maybe long ago, but cross-env hadn't receive the exit event.

This PR uses `node` to run the jest test directly , and skips cross-env, to see if We can find the root cause why Jest exit.

Besides, lower the time-out limit, if error happens , let it fail faster.



## Related links

body:
## Summary

Remove `verbatimModuleSyntax: true` from create-rspack's tsconfig.json.

When using Node <= 22.x and ts-node, `verbatimModuleSyntax: true` will cause an error:

```bash
rspack.config.ts:1:10 - error TS1286: ESM syntax is not allowed in a CommonJS module when 'verbatimModuleSyntax' is enabled.

1 import { defineConfig } from "@rspack/cli";
```

## Related links

- resolve https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/issues/10815
- https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/pull/10674

### [`v3.6.1`](https://redirect.github.com/prettier/prettier/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#361)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/prettier/prettier/compare/3.6.0...3.6.1)

##### TypeScript: Allow const without initializer ([#​17650](https://redirect.github.com/prettier/prettier/pull/17650), [#​17654](https://redirect.github.com/prettier/prettier/pull/17654) by [@​fisker](https://redirect.github.com/fisker))

<!-- prettier-ignore -->

```jsx
// Input
export const version: string;

// Prettier 3.6.0 (--parser=babel-ts)
SyntaxError: Unexpected token (1:21)
> 1 | export const version: string;
    |                     ^

// Prettier 3.6.0 (--parser=oxc-ts)
SyntaxError: Missing initializer in const declaration (1:14)
> 1 | export const version: string;
    |              ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

// Prettier 3.6.1
export const version: string;
```

##### Miscellaneous: Avoid closing files multiple times ([#​17665](https://redirect.github.com/prettier/prettier/pull/17665) by [@​43081j](https://redirect.github.com/43081j))

When reading a file to infer the interpreter from a shebang, we use the
`n-readlines` library to read the first line in order to get the shebang.

This library closes files when it reaches EOF, and we later try close the same
files again. We now close files only if `n-readlines` did not already close
them.

title: chore(ci): including codspeed perfermance comparison into required checks

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

body:
Codspeed performance comparison is a neutral *Check*. And it's written by codspeed's GitHub App.
So we can't get the comparison result in workflow directly.

Here we use a workaround to get the comparison result by taking advance of Codspeed's pull request comment.

After comparison, Codspeed will write/update [comment](https://codspeed.io/docs/integrations/ci/buildkite#3-check-the-results) to the pull request about the performance status.

So we can poll pull request's codspeed bot's comment, check if it contains the commit id of current CI targeted. If so we get the latest comparison, then we do a simple grep to see if the pull request degrade the performance or not, then fail or pass the CI checking.

1. The polling is written in the `check-comment.sh`
2. The polling action should be put in `CI.yaml` other than `reusable-build-bench.yml`; it seems that codspeed will write/update comment after job finishes, so if put polling in `reusable-build-bench.yml`, it will trigger a dead-lock


Here is a failure log: https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/actions/runs/15863460473/job/44726161423?pr=10782#step:3:9
Here is a success log: https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/actions/runs/15865447682/job/44731781135#step:3:9

title: feat: typescript cross module enum inlining

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

labels.name: release: feature
labels.description: release: feature related release(mr only)

body:
## Summary

Support typescript cross module enum inlining

In module enum inlining is already [supported by `builtin:swc-loader` and enabled by default](https://github.com/swc-project/swc/blob/636d7a3830ca3de01ee2078385820e3a37d62343/crates/swc_ecma_transforms_typescript/src/config.rs#L36), and there is no way to turn it off for now 😅 (will add one later)

`rspackExperiments.exportedEnum`: 
- `true`: inline all enum even it's not const
- `"const-only"`: inline only const enum, if there is mutate on enum then you should use this, but you need also disable in module enum inlining for swc, since there is no way to turn it off for a long time so I suspect is there really have usage for mutating enum
- `false`: do nothing, no inline enum

<!-- Describe what this PR does and why. -->

title: perf(zod): prefer to use `partial` to make all properties optional

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

labels.name: release: performance
labels.description: release: performance related release(mr only)

body:
## Summary

Prefer to use `partial` to make all properties optional, this makes the code more readable and can reduce bundle size.

> https://zod.dev/api?id=partial

## Bundle size

- before:

```txt
File (cjs0)     Size       
dist/index.js   850.5 kB
```

- after:

```txt
File (cjs0)     Size       
dist/index.js   843.9 kB
```

## Runtime performance

`optional()` and `partial()` have similar performance.

```bash
hyperfine --warmup 5 --runs 20  'node ./optional.js' 'node ./partial.js'
Benchmark 1: node ./optional.js
  Time (mean ± σ):     201.0 ms ±  14.5 ms    [User: 332.4 ms, System: 25.3 ms]
  Range (min … max):   190.1 ms … 242.9 ms    20 runs
 
Benchmark 2: node ./partial.js
  Time (mean ± σ):     198.0 ms ±   4.1 ms    [User: 332.0 ms, System: 25.0 ms]
  Range (min … max):   192.7 ms … 211.5 ms    20 runs
 
Summary
  node ./partial.js ran
    1.02 ± 0.08 times faster than node ./optional.js
```

- [ ] Documentation updated (or not required).

title: chore(wasm): enable wasm test ci

labels.name: team
labels.description: The issue/pr is created by the member of Rspack.

body:
## TLDR

See README https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/pull/10757/files#diff-41474e04e3d2355fdf11a3a9dd45aba2700642b09ea1d189b7fd0fb2b0132745

## Summary

I will avoid intrusive changes as many as possible. Currently we skip many testcases. I believe some of the failures are related the test harness while others may be related to the bugs of rspack wasm. It could be time-consuming to figure out all of them so in this stage we use the wasm test ci to avoid the regression rather than improve its stability, which will be done in the future.

1. Currently we set `maxWorkers` to 1, `maxConcurrency` to 1 and disable concurrent mode to avoid random failure. But it needs further investigation.
2. Should use Node 20.

### Dashboard:

- @rspack/cli
   - [x] profile: skip all due to lack of system api support
- @rspack/test-tools and webpack-test: skip all snapshots (becuase the enum tag is an `usize`)
   - [x] error snapshot: skip all because the wasm error backtrace bypasses emnapi.
   - [x] module not found: mf, sass-loader: solve with Node 20, because stackblitz uses Node 20.
   - [x] swc wasm plugin related tests:should skip
   - [x] diagnostics (error orders): skip all because I don't want to spend time figuring out the order issues.
   - [x] browserslist related tests: **temporarily** skip due to https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack/blob/cb4cd409f8c73fbb71e1d2740363d62aa84d7bd6/crates/rspack_browserslist/src/load_config.rs
   - [x] pnp related tests: **temporarily** skip due to https://github.com/web-infra-dev/rspack-resolver/pull/21
   - [x] **Temporarily** disable concurrent mode for all tests. I believe there are bugs but I will investigate later.
   - [x] Cache tests: **temporarily** skip due to unknown timeout

## Checklist

<!--- Check and mark with an "x" -->

- [x] Tests updated (or not required).
- [x] Documentation updated (or not required).
